Which is to say I loved the typography shenanigans. I felt at home.

Absolutely loved a more challenging Tuesday. When you’ve been solving for several years like I have, Mon-Wed sometimes tend to solve themselves on autopilot, so this was an awesome surprise. And the puzzle had spunk—at one point I actually clicked the info button just to see whether this was a Robyn Weintraub brainchild. 

About IRENA: I got curious about the Irena Szewińska (Wikipedia spells her name with an acute accent over the n, which is missing from the clue) since I’m a runner and, like the constructor, I’d never heard of her. Actually, I got curious about what IRENAs may have been more well-known to the average solver, and was rather surprised there aren’t many. There’s Irena Sendler, a social worker who saved 2,500 Jewish children during the Holocaust by smuggling them out of the Warsaw Ghetto and then there are two rather minor literary characters, one from Turgenev and one from Milan Kundera. That’s it, though my “research” was limited to Wikipedia and ChatGPT. 

… Which of course made me wonder about the Tuesday clueing of the name of someone whom the constructor himself notes he’d never heard of, but that’s a nit for another day. Of course the crosses were kind and I always appreciate a TIL moment. 

Happy Monday or Tuesday, y’all, depending on your time zone.

The correct phrase is "bald-faced lie"; "bald-faced" is the preferred term when describing a blatant, obvious lie, while "bold-faced" is often mistakenly used but technically means something slightly different, referring to something emphasized or prominent.

Well, I was a little slower than average for a Tuesday, but I guess that was warranted. Mostly I came here to read the bold/bald controversy. I'd already looked up what the style guides say, which confirmed my suspicions. The truth is that although "bald-faced" is "correct", few think about the actual meaning when using this idiom, and in modern usage "bold-faced" is widespread (even though autocorrect doesn't want to let me use it!). It seems to make sense, in that the accused is boldly lying. More importantly, it's the only way to get this entry to work with the theme. Bottom line is that I could care less (so to speak).

And... on that note: Puzzle find today is strangest one I've ever encountered: a Sunday from May 17, 1998 by David J. Kahn and Hillary B. Kahn with the title: "Green eggs and Hamlet." Eight 23 letter grid-spanning theme answers. First clue was "Start of an imaginary soliloquy," and then the rest were all "part 2, part 3, etc." Here are those theme answers: IDONOTLIKEMYDADSBROTHER POISONEDKINGWEDMYMOTHER ILETTHEMTHINKTHATIAMMAD OOPSISTABBEDOPHELIASDAD NOBODYHELPSMEINMYPLIGHT NOWLAERTESANDIWILLFIGHT SWORDSARESWITCHEDINAJAM ATHEATRICALENDINGHAMIAM Could anyone possibly have worked that one out? Who knows. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/17/1998&g=65&d=A I'll shut up now. ....

OOH BABY!  I came into this puzzle in a neutral state, and left it on a high.  I, a wordplay lover, stepped into the box, and my whole time there, I was in my happy place.

Happy to have plenty of unknowns and not-sure-of’s to overcome, and happy to have landed in a word playground.  This was remarkably satisfying and entertaining to fill in.

Such lovely touches!  That wonderful Faulkner quote transforming LAIN from ordinary to a delight.  Words never seen before in the Times puzzle, such as WHAT’D I SAY, NEOLOGISM, and FLAUTAS – and can you believe SUBSCRIPTION has never appeared in a Times puzzle in its 80+ year history?  Or even in any of the major crossword venues?

Then the sweet wordplay not only in clues, like those for DIE, ONES, and more, but as the basis for the theme itself -- the cleverness of CAPITAL ISM and my favorite, SUBSCRIPT ION.  Sweet discoveries popping out all over the place.  Even a rare-in-crossword five-letter semordnilap (DECAF).

What a mood lifter!  Dana, I hope you find crevices of time amidst your studies at Columbia to eke out some more puzzles.  Thank you so much for this!

The UPS clue was a trigger for me -- I have a decades-long feud with the company. So here is a PSA for any US resident sending packages to Canada:

You may be tempted to use UPS, as the rates seem cheaper than other options. But in the fine print of what you sign you agree that the recipient will pay the brokerage charges. These may run to $30 to $40 CND for a small package with minimal value. Most people are unaware of this when they choose UPS.

All this talk about BOLD-FACED piqued my curiosity, so I decided to do a little research. As I suspected, many sources state the original term was BAREFACED LIE, which evolved into BALD-FACED. Nowadays, most commonly BOLD-FACED is used, even though AP style demands BALD-FACED. Other sources say BOLD-FACED came first, however others say the first appearance in print comes from Shakespeare, who used BAREFACED. Anyway, we only have to look at the misuse of the words LAY and LIE to know we should just toss in the towel.

I do the NYT and WSJ crosswords daily. There are days when both puzzles contain the same answer (but clued differently). I chalked up this bit of crossword deja vu to the fact that some words seem to routinely find their way into a given puzzle—when was the last time a puzzle didn’t have “aria” in it?

But 56 Across in today’s NYT also shows up in today’s WSJ and that frankly is too much. I’m no conspiracy theorist, but the Evil Genius who controls the globe’s crossword industry is getting sloppy.

Merriam-Webster says bold(-/ )faced lies exist. I agree. The English language is still evolving. After all today's neologism is tomorrow's literature. It helps make up for the words we lose. Just ask Lewis Carroll.

@Scott 

The fact that it makes more sense doesn't mean it's the original term.  It makes more sense today because with word processing so common now, we are more aware of bold typeface than when we were using typewriters.  

That also means it's ripe for supplanting (at least partially) a similar phrase that now makes less sense.  After all, what does "bald-faced" (or the original, "barefaced") mean anyway.  Clean-shaven?  Maskless?  It's ripe for being supplanted.

And that's how language changes.  Something comes along that sounds better than what was there before.  Some pedants insist it has to be the old, "correct" way, but usage eventually wins out.  I believe that as the century progresses, bald-faced will continue to lose ground to bold-faced.

Anyway, the puzzle is free to use anything that is common usage.  It doesn't have to be the most common expression, nor one that has 100% pedantic acceptance (cf. WHAT'D I SAY).

I don't feel there's a nit to pick here at all and I'm amazed that so many people are joining the chorus.

@Sam Lyons - the Polish letter ń has a kreska, not an acute accent. Just as German Länder has an umlaut but English coördinate has a diaeresis. They look similar, but are not the same.

The kreska on an n indicates palatalization. In the context of -ińska as a name ending, the ń becomes a nasal semivowel; there is no hard n in the pronunciation at all.

@Srella 

Meanings of words and expressions change over time, and those are two cases where they have.  M-W reports the news; it doesn't make it.  When a usage gains enough traction, it becomes legitimate because most people understand that meaning, and it has been used effectively in speech and, especially, writing.

In the case of "bold-faced", the new version makes as much sense, or even more, than the previous one (which wasn't even the original one; that was barefaced).  In the case of "begs the question", the new meaning developed because the old one didn't make sense to most people.

To calm your anger, just realize that language changes, and you've lived a long enough life to have seen it happen.

And good luck with trying to use "beg the question" in its original meaning. It's thoroughly skunked, and the only thing to do is avoid the phrase entirely, in either meaning. 
See also"enormity" and "refute".

At least "bold-/bald-/bare-faced" shares a single sense among several words, so you can merrily choose whichever version floats your boat, without fear of confusing your meaning.
(I'm for "bare-faced", myself.)
